Definitions.Definition_Content:
A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
A field is a commutative division ring.

An element a of a ring R is called a zero divisor if there exists an element b in R - {0} such that ab=0 or ba=0. Fields and skew fields do not admit any zero divisors, except for 0, the trivial zero divisor.
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.

The degree of a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], denoted by deg f, is defined as the maximum i such that a_i 
eq 0. The degree is assigned -
infty for the zero polynomial.

For a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X] with deg f=n 
geq 0, the coefficient a_n is called the leading coefficient. If a_n=1, the polynomial is called monic.

Theorems.Theorem_Content:
For polynomials f, g in a polynomial ring R[X], the degree of the sum (f+g) is at most the maximum of the degrees of f and g, and the degree of the product (f 
cdot g) is at most the sum of their degrees. If R is an integral domain, then deg(f 
cdot g) = deg f + deg g.
If R is an integral domain, then the polynomial ring R[X] is also an integral domain, and the units of R[X] are exactly the units of R.
For a ring R and a polynomial g in R[X] with a unit as its leading coefficient, every polynomial f in R[X] can be uniquely expressed as f=qg+r where q, r are polynomials in R[X] and deg r < deg g.
